head.title: Sea Carnivores Move In At Las Vegas Casino

identified-content.org: Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino (Las Vegas, Nev)

hedline.hl1: Sea Carnivores Move In At Las Vegas Casino

abstract.p: Aquarium featuring venomous tropical fish, carnivorous water monitors and 10 species of shark opens at Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev (S)

block.p: An aquarium featuring some of the most feared predators of the sea -- venomous tropical fish, carnivorous water monitors (a type of lizard that measures up to seven feet long) and 10 species of shark -- recently opened at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.

An aquarium featuring some of the most feared predators of the sea -- venomous tropical fish, carnivorous water monitors (a type of lizard that measures up to seven feet long) and 10 species of shark -- recently opened at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.

The Shark Reef at Mandalay Bay is constructed to resemble the ruins of an ancient temple slowly sinking into the sea. A path winds through the temple's courtyard and gradually descends, to suggest that the visitor is going underwater.

Fourteen exhibits range from a touch tank of small stingrays and horseshoe crabs to a display of moon jellyfish. A 1.3-million-gallon tank features the largest sharks, including nurse sharks that reach 12 feet, as well as moray eels, sea turtles weighing up to 300 pounds, and southern stingrays. Staff members in scuba gear have an underwater communication system that lets them discuss the animals and answer questions from visitors as they do their work.
The 105,000-square-foot aquarium was developed in conjunction with the Vancouver Aquarium Marine Science Center in Vancouver, British Columbia.

The Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino is at 3950 Las Vegas Boulevard South, Las Vegas, Nev., (877) 632-7400. The Shark Reef is open daily 10 a.m. to 11 p.m. Admission is $12.95, $9.95 ages 12 and under; 5 and under are free.
